children.subject: To add, if you were to use the number that's on your transcript (which is the overall GPA), then it would be easily verifiable that that is indeed your GPA in case some company were to ask for your transcript. But if you reported your technical GPA or CS Major GPA for example, and that turned out to be much higher than your overall GPA that is on your transcript, then in case a company asked for your transcript, the discrepancy might cause eyebrows to be raised, and might require additional clarification on your part as to how you arrived at that number you reported on your resume. BUT, almost no companies ask for your transcript (with the famous exception of Google), so it would be a very rare issue, if at all one.
Interesting, I see. I have 4.0 technical gpa but have the overall gpa lowered due to breadth course, although not by much. Which is why I was wondering if it was ok to just report technical gpa.
Just put the 4.0 then, you'll be fine on that front for industry either way if you're around that number.

Ok, I think I’ll include the gpa on my LinkedIn and resume then. in the exception of google though, what should I do if my LinkedIn displays the technical gpa while my transcript displays otherwise? Also I was thinking of not explicitly reporting the label technical gpa on my transcript/ resume but just saying gpa

(I’m just really proud of my performance in Cal in tech courses, that’s why I was wondering:))

Google won't bother looking at your LinkedIn, just your resume and possibly transcript to ensure you're not failing or anything. A 3.9 vs 4.0 discrepancy on transcript vs. resume shouldn't make a difference. You'll be fine. You could even mention both GPAs on your resume to be extra safe, but really, it's a moot point.

Put whichever is higher. I've seen people put all sorts of filters on their GPA ("technical", "CS major", "EE major" etc.). My personal belief is to put overall GPA, because as long as you don't go out of your way to take classes that do not satisfy any requirements, but simply to boost your GPA, the overall GPA seems to be the most unbiased overview of your performance in college without any filters applied to it and is the same number as what's on your transcript. But in my case my overall GPA would also be higher than any other filter that I could hope to put on it, so it works out just fine for me.

history.content:
On resume, when people report GPA is their GPA usually just the technical GPA, or do people usually report overall GPA?

I was thinking of reporting just technical GPA
history.subject: Reporting GPA on resumes
